docs.lead_paragraph: After six years of twice-weekly psychotherapy sessions, Eric had plenty of insight. But his anxiety level had barely changed. He was still bedeviled by a ceaseless urge to wash his hands and shameful and repetitive violent thoughts. Out of desperation and against the wishes of his therapist, he visited my office to discuss the possibility of medication.

headline.main: Like Drugs, Talk Therapy Can Change Brain Chemistry

docs.abstract: Dr Richard Friedman article on new evidence suggesting that use of either cognitive behavior therapy or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressants can result in changes in brain chemistry that aid patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug that lowers cholesterol also reduces inflammation of blood vessels, a study being published today has found, and does so quickly enough that the drug may find a new role in treating heart attacks. In recent years, research has suggested that inflammation may rank alongside high cholesterol as a possible cause of heart disease. Inflammation also causes complications after heart attacks and heart surgery.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by Dr Robert Eckel of University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, published in journal Circulation, concludes that cholesterol-reducing drug simvastatin also reduces inflammation of blood vessels and may be useful in treating heart attacks and reducing complications after heart surgery (M)
docs.snippet: A drug that lowers cholesterol also reduces inflammation of blood vessels, a study being published today has found, and does so quickly enough that the drug may find a new role in treating heart attacks.    In recent years, research has suggested...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. J. Allan Hobson, 69, a Harvard psychiatrist and dream researcher, arrived for an interview, he had a notebook filled with his writings, photographs of his extended family and renderings of his summer house in Italy. ''This will help introduce me,'' Dr. Hobson said. ''I believe you need to get to know about me quickly,'' he added, demonstrating an easy informality and perhaps belying the stereotypes about uptight psychiatrists.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/J. Allan Hobson; A Rebel Psychiatrist Calls Out to His Profession

docs.abstract: Interview with Harvard Universy psychiatrist Dr J Allan Hobson, director of Massachusetts Mental Health Center's Laboratory of Neurophysiology, whose latest book, Out of Its Mind: Psychiatry in Crisis: A Call for Reform, co-written with Jonathan A Leonard, has just been published in paperback; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to extend New York's smoking ban to all offices, bars and restaurants -- even pool halls, bowling alleys and bingo parlors -- would not make the city the first to have such a law. California and dozens of towns and counties already have similar laws. But with all eyes on New York, a new law would send a strong message to the many cities and states that lag on this important health measure.

headline.main: A Jubilant Barroom Toast: To Smoke-Free Air

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column supports New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposal to extend smoking ban to all offices, bars and restaurants; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since 1998, all graduates of foreign medical schools seeking licenses in the United States have been required to pass a clinical skills test to determine whether they can effectively deal with patients. The test, involving actors pretending to be ill, is given to foreign students who have passed the first two steps of the three-part national medical licensing examination, which American medical school graduates are required to take, and an English proficiency test.

headline.main: Patient Gets Role in Test For Doctors

docs.abstract: Article on pilot program at University of Pennsylvania, Thomas Jefferson University and Temple University medical schools that tests clinical skills and 'bedside manners' of foreign and American medical school graduates; Assn of American Medical Colleges president Dr Jordan Cohen asks National Board of Medical Examiners and Federation of State Medical Boards to find less expensive alternative to test, which uses trained actors and costs students about $950 plus travel expenses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Essential Medication Guidebook to Healthy Aging,'' by Merck-Medco, edited by Dr. Les Paul and Dr. Becky Nagle, Ballantine Books, $18.95. Changes that occur with aging often escape notice, including new problems with the kidneys, the liver and other organs. And any number of the organs can create problems when certain drugs are taken.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews books The Essential Medication Guidebook to Healthy Aging by Merck-Medco, edited by Dr Les Paul and Dr Becky Nagel, and All About Fibromyalgia by Dr Daniel J Wallace and Janice Brock Wallace; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The flu season is months away, but a vaccine expert from the Mayo Clinic is calling on doctors to start preparing a concerted effort to increase flu vaccinations, citing a study that found vaccinations cut deaths or hospitalizations from influenza by up to half among people older than 65. The study, published this month in the journal Clinical Infectious Diseases, tracked more than 100,000 people through two flu seasons.

headline.main: When the Flu Is Taken Lightly

docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Eelko Hak of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Minneapolis, published in journal Clinical Infectious Diseases, finds that flu vaccinations cut deaths or hospitalizations from influenza by up to 50 percent among people older than 65; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The absurdity struck me as I stood at the sink in my hospital room, brushing and flossing. There I was back in the hospital again, after five months of chemotherapy, a newly discovered blood clot in my pelvis and a bevy of hematologists scurrying about, trying to discover the proper dosage of blood thinners for my latest complication. And I am still flossing!

headline.main: Finding Moments of Comfort and Humor While Facing Cancer Treatment

docs.abstract: Barbara Gamarekian Cases column describes comfort she has found in family and friends and glimpses of humor after surgery and as she goes through treatment for peritoneal cancer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Monique Brown, a writer and editor from Brooklyn, visited a physician, worried about her heavy periods and bleeding between menstruation. Her disorder was diagnosed as fibroids, she said, noncancerous tumors that can grow in the uterus. ''It's normal,'' she recalled being told. ''Everybody has them.''

headline.main: Women Seek Choices When Fibroid Tumors Strike

docs.abstract: Article on noncancerous uterine fibroid tumors and alternatives to hysterectomies that women of childbearing age are beginning to demand; Sens Jean Carnahan, James Jeffords and Barbara Mikulski have introduced legislation calling for allocating $10 million a year for four years toward research on fibroids through National Institutes of Health as well as educational campaign; photo; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: How accurate are infrared thermometers that measure temperature through the ears? Accurate enough for a parent trying to decide whether a child has a fever, but not accurate enough for an emergency room physician in a situation that calls for getting it just right, according to a study published on Saturday in The Lancet. Researchers from the University of Liverpool collected data from 44 studies that compared readings from infrared ear thermometers and rectal thermometers, which are widely considered the most accurate way to measure core temperature. The team found that the average difference between the two methods was relatively small, about a half-degree Fahrenheit.

headline.main: In the Ear and Off the Mark

docs.abstract: University of Liverpool researchers, in study published in Lancet, finds that infrared thermometers that measure temperature in ear are not accurate enough for emergency room physicians to make accurate assessments; drawing (M)
